question: What is the CCDB?
answer: The CCDB is the portal to your account with the Alliance where you can find information on your roles in projects, allocated resources, and usage statistics.

question: What functionalities are available on the CCDB portal?
answer: On the portal, users can register, manage personal information and roles, apply for the Resource Allocation Competition (RAC), and manage RAP information and membership.

question: What is a CCI and why is it important for users?
answer: A CCI is a unique personal and national identifier created for you when you register at https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca. It is a string of 3 letters followed by 3 digits, for example: abc-123.

question: Who is eligible to register for a CCI with the CCDB?
answer: To register, you must either be a faculty member at a Canadian institution registered with the CCDB, or be sponsored by such a faculty member. Sponsored individuals can include graduate students and research staff.

question: What is a 'role' in the context of Alliance computational resources?
answer: A role is an identifier representing a person's position (e.g., faculty, graduate student), institution, and sponsor. A valid and up-to-date role is necessary to access computational resources.

question: What should a user do if their institution, sponsor, or position changes regarding their CCDB role?
answer: If your institution, sponsor, or position changes, you need to apply for a new role rather than updating the old one, to maintain accurate records for governmental funding agencies.

question: What is the format of a CCRI?
answer: A CCRI follows the convention CCI <dash> 2 digits. For example, for a user with CCI abc-123, a first role's CCRI would be abc-123-01.

question: What is a CCRI?
answer: A CCRI is the unique identifier for your role. A single CCI can be linked to more than one CCRI over time, and every job run on a national cluster is attributed to a CCRI.

question: What is a Resource Allocation Project (RAP)?
answer: RAPs provide PIs access to national computational resources. Each RAP has a unique RAPI and an associated group name. RAPs represent groups of researchers to whom computing resources are allocated.

question: Why are computing resources allocated to RAPs instead of individuals?
answer: Computing resources are allocated to RAPs (groups of researchers), not individuals, because the word 'project' is too ambiguous for reporting purposes, and to provide statistics on how facilities are used.

question: What are the two main types of Resource Allocation Projects (RAPs)?
answer: The two main types of RAPs are Default RAPs and RAC RAPs.

question: What is a Default RAP?
answer: A Default RAP is automatically created when a PI role is activated. It manages storage and cloud quotas for default and Rapid Access Service, allowing PIs and sponsored users opportunistic use of compute resources with the lowest priority. Its CCDB convention is 'def-profname'.

question: What is a RAC RAP?
answer: A RAC RAP is created when a PI receives an award through the Resource Allocation Competition (RAC) application process. Its RAPI typically takes the form 'abc-123-ab', with group names varying based on allocation type (e.g., 'rrg-profname-xx' for HPC, 'crg-profname-xx' for Cloud).

question: What is a group name in the context of Resource Allocation Projects?
answer: A group name is an alias for the Research Allocation Project Identifier (RAPI). It has a unique one-to-one mapping with a RAPI and is often easier for users to remember.

question: What is the typical group name convention for a Default RAP?
answer: The typical group name convention for a Default RAP is 'def-[profname][-xx]'.

question: What are the typical group name conventions for HPC resource RAPs?
answer: For HPC resource RAPs, the typical group name conventions are 'rrg-[profname][-xx]' for RRG/HPC and 'rpp-[profname][-xx]' for RPP/HPC.

question: What are the typical group name conventions for Cloud resource RAPs?
answer: For Cloud resource RAPs, the typical group name conventions are 'crg-[profname][-xx]' for RRG/Cloud and 'cpp-[profname][-xx]' for RPP/Cloud.

question: How is a group name used within the system?
answer: The group name is used as a POSIX group name with an associated POSIX group ID and is propagated through LDAP in the dn attribute, for example: 'dn: cn=rpp-profname,ou=Group,dc=computecanada,dc=ca'.

question: Who has access to a Default RAP?
answer: All of a PI's activated sponsored user roles are always members of the PI's default RAP. This membership cannot be modified, though a PI can deactivate any role they sponsor.

question: How does membership work for a RAC RAP with HPC resources?
answer: For RAC RAPs with HPC resources, CCDB automatically adds all of the PI's sponsored user roles, all associated Co-PI roles, and all sponsored users roles of all associated Co-PIs. Any new role sponsored by the PI after RAP creation is also automatically added.

question: How does membership work for a RAC RAP with Cloud resources?
answer: For RAC RAPs with Cloud resources allocated, only the PI is added as a member at the time of creation.

question: Can a PI modify membership for a RAC RAP?
answer: Yes, the PI can modify the membership of any of their RAC RAPs at any time. Any user with an active Alliance account can be added as a member of a RAC RAP.

question: What are the three RAP membership permission levels?
answer: There are three RAP membership permission levels: Owner, Manager, and Member.

question: What are the permissions of a RAP 'Owner'?
answer: The PI is the sole owner of the RAP and all associated allocations. This cannot be changed. The owner can add or remove RAP managers and members.

question: What are the permissions and limitations of a RAP 'Manager'?
answer: A Manager has elevated permission (on CCDB only) delegated by the owner or another manager to make membership changes. Managers can use the PI's allocation, but cannot make changes on the project/nearline file systems (e.g., change ownership, apply ACLs, manage permissions on Globus) on behalf of the PIs.

question: What are the permissions of a RAP 'Member'?
answer: Members can use the PI’s allocation in the corresponding cluster(s) but cannot make any modifications to the RAP membership.

question: How is RAP membership represented and used in the system?
answer: RAP membership is represented as a group in LDAP, defining a group of users authorized to submit jobs against the RAPI (ID of the RAP) and share files within the same Unix group.

question: Can I sign up for a new Alliance account if I had one in the past but my position or sponsor changed, or I lost my password?
answer: No, each person can only have one Alliance account (one CCI). Duplicate CCI requests are refused. If your position or sponsor changed, you should apply for a new role with your existing account. If you lost your password, you can reset it.

question: What should I do if I have an existing CCI but my position or sponsor has changed?
answer: You should log in with your existing account and apply for a new role through the 'apply for a new role' form at https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca/me/add_role.

question: What should I do if I forgot my Alliance account password?
answer: You can reset your password at https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca/security/forgot. If you can no longer access the email address on file, you should email accounts@tech.alliancecan.ca for assistance.

question: How do I sign up for an Alliance account?
answer: To sign up, go to the register link at https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca/account_application. You will need to accept certain policies and agreements, which can be reviewed on the Alliance website.

question: Where can I view the agreements I've accepted on CCDB after my account is approved?
answer: Once your account has been approved, you can see the agreements you have accepted at any time on CCDB by going to 'My Account --> Agreements' (https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca/agreements/user_index).

question: What are the two main types of roles when applying for an account?
answer: The two main types of roles are sponsor roles (often Primary Investigators or PIs) and sponsored roles.

question: Who can be a sponsor (Primary Investigator) for a role?
answer: Only faculty members from Canadian post-secondary academic institutions who are eligible for CFI funding can be sponsors. Administrators leading research projects who are not faculty must contact accounts@tech.alliancecan.ca for accommodations.

question: What are the categories of sponsored roles?
answer: Sponsored roles fall into two groups: internal, for applicants part of the supervisor's local group, and external, for collaborators from a different institution.

question: What are some available roles for students?
answer: Available student roles include undergraduate, masters, and doctoral.

question: What roles are available for researchers affiliated with the same institution as the PI?
answer: Roles for researchers affiliated with the same institution as the PI include postdoctoral fellow and researcher (only if paid by the PI's institution).

question: What role is available for collaborators affiliated with a different institution than the PI?
answer: The role for collaborators affiliated with a different institution than the PI is 'external collaborator,' who must specify an institution different from that of the PI.

question: What happens after I submit my account request?
answer: You will receive an email to confirm your provided email address. If you are a PI, your application will be approved by Federation staff. Otherwise, it needs confirmation from your identified PI sponsor before Federation staff approval.

question: Who should I contact for help with questions not covered in the FAQ?
answer: For any questions not covered in the FAQ, you should send an email to accounts@tech.alliancecan.ca.
